content.body: hng
I thought insisting on publishing HTML5 as HTML4 was bad, then I read about HTMLnext.pdf
"Silos in the Working Group structure which inhibits alignment"
What does that mean?
It means that SVG reinvents anchors instead of using HTML
does not find any relevant definition of "silo" in the dictionary
Is it Microspeak or something?
No, it's standard
You have siloing when separate groups/departments/etc don't communicate with each other
So it's standard bureaucrat speak, then?
Why is HTMLnext.pdf written in bureaucrat jargon instead of technojargon?
grumbles
Standard anyone-who's-worked-in-an-organization-with-more-than-a-few-hundred-people
Right, so bureaucrat-speak.
You know, I think I agree with most of HTMLnext.pdf, but I dislike it anyway because of the obnoxious way it's written.
It could have been the founding document of WHATWG for large parts
it's only 7 years late!
But it's there, from Microsoft. I'd say that's significant.
http://www.w3.org/2004/04/webapps-cdf-ws/papers/opera.html is the actual founding document
Well, it argues in favor of modularization.
(written in html, not pdf)
Also emphasizes tests, which the WHATWG . . . has not.
"Simply stated, there is evidence of overdesign."  +1001
Hixie's timeline has, what, 10 years blocked off for writing the test suite?
yeah, what Dashiva said
also, at the time the whatwg was formed, test suites were not controversial -- everyone agreed we needed them
(and still do)
(and work is ongoing)
This appears to be arguing that the tests should be written along with the specs, not that we should all agree we want comprehensive test suites and then not write them for seven years and counting.
(the fundamental principles of the WHATWG work however are still not clearly uncontroversial)
AryehGregor: yeah, i don't think anyone disagrees with that position
saying it should happen doesn't make it happen
Unless you're a manager at a company who gets to tell your subordinates what to do.  :)
Or maybe the developers at Microsoft are the ones who decided to write all those tests, I don't know.  But they say they'd like to submit them earlier in the process next time, which is nice.
Go Microsoft.
Dashiva: "HTMLnext.pdf"?
http://twitter.com/html5douche/status/29222926252
(I'm not sure I ever anticipated writing the words "Go Microsoft" without inserting something like like "to hell" in there, but there you have it.)
ta
I'm sure there's a more official link somewhere
I just used Google.
I guess there's no way to try BBEdit for free
AryehGregor: nothing stopping them from submitting them right now, why would they wait until next time?
anyway, i agree that much of what they say is on the ball
and i'm glad they've finally joined the party (?)
seems you can download a 30-day trial copy of BBEdit here: http://www.barebones.com/products/bbedit/demo.html
appears to have pretty good support for new HTML5 elements
can be added through completion and such
I'm not sure that document (HTMLnext.pdf) tells me anything new or even proposes a feasible process to fix things

I actually think the problem is that something like the WHATWG is missing in the W3C - a collaboration between browser vendors to determine which of the specified stuff will actually go into the browser
it's not the individual specs that make a difference - it's the implementation
needs a trusted benevolent dictator to some extent ;)
tim is the w3c's benevolent dictator
but he works on the semantic web, not html
Tim works on a lot of stuff
he's certainly paying a lot of attention to the HTML work
the TAG is too
nessy: how is that collaboration not happening at the W3C?
fully agree the implementation is what matters
and that collaboration among the UA implementors is what is needed to make it happen
nessy: or to put it in other words, how can the collaboration be made to happen better at the W3C?
or what does it seem is preventing from happening the way it should be optimally happening?

MikeSmith: the collaboration between UAs is only really now happening again with HTML5 - I was referring to how there wasn't really any concerted progress beforehand, only little bits here and there without a bigger picture for moving HTML5 forward - and Tim seemed like he had lost interest in moving HTML forward and was rather working towards eliminating it
ah, OK
I can't say I'd agree that Tim is doing anything to work towards eliminating it

seeming as Tim is not leading the HTML WG - which to me is the heart of the Web - it just seems that the W3C isn't really the right forum to lead the web - but I don't want to sound unthankful - the W3C has done lots of great stuff ;)
I would think Tim's public comments indicate that he doesn't think people should be wedded to the XML syntax
s/seeming/seeing/
I don't like that phrase "lead the Web" much
i like the xml syntax :>
personally
I think market needs lead the Web
I said "leading the HTML WG"
ah … hmm...
oh, I meant the "the right forum to lead the web" part you said
I meant technically
I think technically the Web should be led by market needs
the market had clearly spoken in 2000 that video on the Web was needed - the only ones listening were Macromedia
yep
and the same for many other features that did a lot more to the Web than the whole XML craze
anyway - I think we're now in a productive phase again and that's great
yeah
and we have Microsoft increasingly more involved in that productive phase too
investing more in the Web platform
and Adobe too
for that matter
and Google :)
yeah
i still want jng back, btw :>
it would help if there were a standard to replace animated GIFs
it's pretty annoying that there isn't any lossy image format which also supports alpha
mng
apng
you don't really want to replace a 5mb gif with a 4mb apng, do you?
I don't really want people to use 5MB animated GIFs at all - that's what video is for
video is even worse
shall i use H.264 or Ogg Theora?
webm
well, jng would cover some area which isn't covered by other formats
to be honest it is covered by png32, but it's ridiculously big
on some page i did recently there was a >300kb png32. it was the only choice. a quantized png8 didn't look any good
a 70-80kb jng would have worked just fine
maybe a 50kb one would have worked too
makes their reasoning sorta funny, really. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=195280
MikeSmith: I use TextMate for editing anything
including HTML
MikeSmith, try komodo edit. it's ace :)
cure list bullets in HTMLnext.pdf
s/cure/cute/
on my way to TPAC
curious about the XML vs HTML topic
but mostly looking forward to meeting people
annevk: see you there
MikeSmith, when are you arriving?
I get to the airport at 22:30
ah, I should be there shortly
staying at the "Hotel Mercure Brotteaux"
according to this email, I'm staying at "HOTEL DES CONGRES"
no idea how to get there and no idea how to get from there to TPAC
annevk: I expect to get there by giving th address to a taxi driver and I expect to walk to TPAC
the latter sounds great
aside: I'm shocked, just, shocked, wow, just, wow at JF talking about my "myopic view" as a figure of speech with a negative connotation when I actually have myopia.
I guess I end up doing the former too, though I was hoping to take a bus or something
already took a taxi this morning as I was way late and it was pretty boring
I wonder if JF is around
he has an awesome mustache
annevk, hsivonen - I have to drop off. See you both some time tomorrow
good trip man
cheers
Oh god, css gradients follow different syntax in every browser! And *they all suck*!
Is there a hidden standard somewhere in preparation?
espadrine: The draft standard at http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-images is the official one, and it's what Firefox follows.
espadrine: Webkit's gradients were created as an experiment before this draft was written, and in fact inspired the current draft due to their suckiness.
espadrine: IE's gradients are some horrifying filter abomination, and shall not be discussed further.
espadrine: Opera doesn't have explicit gradient support, but you can hack it in via SVG backgrounds (which should also work in Webkit and FF, iirc).
The draft syntax may change somewhat to fix bugs and rough spots that have come up in implementation, particularly regarding transitioning/animating gradients.
arrived
hsivonen, you around already?
TabAtkinsTPAC: thanks... At least there's one implementation!
TabAtkinsTPAC: for what it's worth, they did quite a good job in removing the cruft from the initial webkit experiment!
"they" = me
So thanks!
Hixie, yes looks like (re FlieAPI use of sequence)
annevk:  Is http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/domcore/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#clone trying to say that cloning documents wouldn't be supported?
Though, when cloning a document "new ownerDocument" would be null
smaug____, I think we should support cloning documents
smaug____, there's some kind of hairy thing with DocumentType nodes there
smaug____, I think the silly thing is that adoptNode() would not work while importNode would
annevk: have you figured out, by any chance, if there's a way to get food near the hotel at this hour?
you have to walk quite a bit unfortunately
it's about fifteen minutes walk to the nearest district of kinds and I'm not sure what is open
but maybe the reception knows some kind of snack place closer by
too bad you just came in
just came back from dinner with the CSS guys
annevk: thanks. I'll resort to my snack reserve
whoa, Maciej is here
I guess it makes sense, but still unexpected
the hotel network is sad. :-(
something doesn't work? or the speed?
drops OpenVPN and ssh over OpenVPN all the time
or the weird customized username/password setup?
that, too
ooh, I have not tried VPN yet
hopefully VPN works at TPAC
and the ethernet cable is dead
Pure guys. Where in the world are you?
romeo_: Lyon, France
has never been to France
s/pure/poor/
English is hard
romeo_:
euh, sorry about that
there's also lots of rain here, but sun is coming Tuesday I'm told
g'night all
is gonna try to get eight hours
per spec is innerHTML supposed to work in an html5 math element?
david_carlisle: innerHTML seems to be defined on HTMLElement and HTMLDocument, and I assume MathML elements aren't those interfaces, so I'd guess it shouldn't work
(I'm not entirely confident on this though)
(but I can't find anything that indicates it should work)
Philip`: doesn't appear to work in FF4 or webkit nightlies, but i was sort of hoping it would
And then having it on Element just vary it depending upon the HTMLness flag on the owner document?
something like that yes
